In a disjunctive syllogism, if one of the disjuncts is eliminated, the other disjunct must be true. However, the second premise only eliminates one of the disjuncts (being on his wrist), but it does not provide any information about the other disjunct (charging on the dresser). The second premise only provides a possibility, not a necessity.
